title: If my Greek family is Arvanite, could I consider myself Greek and Albanian? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes you could. An Albanian in our eyes denotes anyone of Albanian ethnic origin, it’s axiomatic, whereas being a Greek in the post 1860 world has mostly been a question of conforming to specific Church-set criteria - with the foremost being an Orthodox Christian under their purview - and has nothing to do with ethnicity. In parallelism, even if your boot sector has been messed with due to geopolitical/religious intricacies, your hardware and BIOS are still from the authentic stock. Mind you, grek for us up to the 1860s simply denoted Albanians living in the south of the peninsula, it wasn’t considered a different ethnicity, just a geographical designation (see also What is the origin of the word Greek?). Here’s also a map called “Greece as divided in her provinces”, published in Venice, Italy, 1781, by Antonio Zatta illustrating it:  As Arvanite author Aristeidis Kollias (Aristidh Kola) said, commenting the very map, this was also how Albanians that led the Greek war against Turkey in the 1820s saw things. Quoting him: “Its value does not consist in the accuracy of spatial description, but in the conviction that Albania was a Greek province! This was the conviction shared by the very people that 40 years later would rise up in the Greek Revolution. When Karaiskakis left Rumelia in order to sew his famed Shkodran costume, in Shkodër, North Albania, he knew he wasn’t going to some foreign state or some foreign people. And neither did anyone else of the heroes of 1821 ever think that a time would come when the Greek Nation would become “copë e çika” [Alb: in pieces], that one part of it would separate that much from the other, that they’d wish to become not only different nations, but what’s more even enemies! It could be comprehensible for Albania and Greece to be different states, but different nations, never!” Under the prism of this Historical reality, today’s Greeks (inhabitants of Greece and Albanians) should all of us understand that the borders of the Greek Nation start from Lower Italy and passing through the Balkan peninsula they end in the coast of Asia Minor, wherein millions of Albanians still live today. This whole space that was inhabited by Greeks in antiquity it’s not at all incidental that is still being inhabited today by Albanians.
